metadata.title: Boxes | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page describing the Boxes UI component, which creates visually distinct groups of logically related information and components. The document covers best practices, content guidelines, and platform-specific considerations for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, and visionOS.
metadata.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

content.text: A box creates a visually distinct group of logically related information and components.

content.description: A stylized illustration demonstrating the Box UI component concept. The image shows a coral/salmon colored rounded rectangle (the box) containing multiple horizontal content rows represented as elongated rounded rectangles of varying widths. The content rows are arranged vertically within the box, stacked from top to bottom. The rows appear in different shades of coral/pink, with some being shorter and some longer, suggesting different types of content items. Outside the box on both left and right sides are bidirectional arrows indicating the box's horizontal dimensions/margins. Below the box is another bidirectional arrow indicating vertical spacing or the box's relationship to content below it. The overall color palette is warm coral/salmon tones on a light peachy background.
content.composition: Centered box container with content rows stacked vertically inside. Measurement arrows positioned outside the box on left, right, and bottom to indicate spacing and dimensions.
content.technicalDetails: Vector illustration showing UI box component with placeholder content representing grouped interface elements
content.contextualRelevance: This hero illustration visually demonstrates the Box component concept - showing how a box groups related content items together within a visually distinct container, with arrows indicating how the box creates separation and spacing from surrounding interface elements.

content.text: By default, a box uses a visible border or background color to separate its contents from the rest of the interface. A box can also include a title.

Prefer keeping a box relatively small in comparison with its containing view. As a box's size gets close to the size of the containing window or screen, it becomes less effective at communicating the separation of grouped content, and it can crowd other content.
content.leadSentence: Prefer keeping a box relatively small in comparison with its containing view.

content.text: Consider using padding and alignment to communicate additional grouping within a box. A box's border is a distinct visual element — adding nested boxes to define subgroups can make your interface feel busy and constrained.
content.leadSentence: Consider using padding and alignment to communicate additional grouping within a box.

content.text: Provide a succinct introductory title if it helps clarify the box's contents. The appearance of a box helps people understand that its contents are related, but it might make sense to provide more detail about the relationship. Also, a title can help VoiceOver users predict the content they encounter within the box.
content.leadSentence: Provide a succinct introductory title if it helps clarify the box's contents.

content.text: If you need a title, write a brief phrase that describes the contents. Use sentence-style capitalization. Avoid ending punctuation unless you use a box in a settings pane, where you append a colon to the title.
content.leadSentence: If you need a title, write a brief phrase that describes the contents.

content.text: No additional considerations for visionOS. Not supported in tvOS or watchOS.
By default, iOS and iPadOS use the secondary and tertiary background colors in boxes.
By default, macOS displays a box's title above it.
To submit feedback on documentation, visit Feedback Assistant.
content.additionalText: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

pages.pageSummary: This is the Apple Human Interface Guidelines documentation page for the Boxes UI component. The page explains that boxes create visually distinct groups of logically related information and components. It provides best practices for using boxes (keep them relatively small, use padding instead of nested boxes), content guidelines (use succinct titles with sentence-style capitalization), and platform-specific considerations for iOS/iPadOS (uses secondary/tertiary background colors) and macOS (displays title above the box). The page notes that boxes are not supported on tvOS or watchOS. Developer documentation links point to GroupBox for SwiftUI and NSBox for AppKit.

crossPageElements.runningHeaders: Apple Developer Documentation - Design - Human Interface Guidelines
crossPageElements.runningFooters: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

sections.title: Boxes
sections.summary: Introduces the Box component as a UI element that creates visually distinct groups of logically related information using borders or background colors.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Provides two key guidelines: keep boxes relatively small compared to their container, and use padding/alignment instead of nested boxes for subgrouping.

sections.title: Content
sections.summary: Guidelines for box titles: use succinct introductory titles when helpful for clarity and VoiceOver accessibility, with sentence-style capitalization and no ending punctuation except colons in settings panes.

sections.title: Platform considerations

subsections.title: iOS, iPadOS
subsections.summary: iOS and iPadOS use secondary and tertiary background colors in boxes by default.

subsections.title: macOS
subsections.summary: macOS displays a box's title above the box by default.

sections.summary: Platform-specific behaviors for boxes. Not supported on tvOS or watchOS. No additional considerations for visionOS.

sections.title: Resources

subsections.title: Related
subsections.summary: Links to the Layout HIG page.

subsections.title: Developer documentation
subsections.summary: Links to GroupBox (SwiftUI) and NSBox (AppKit) API documentation.

sections.summary: Provides related HIG documentation and developer API documentation links.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document follows Apple's standard HIG documentation structure: it begins with a title and brief description, followed by a hero illustration demonstrating the concept. The main content flows through Best practices (usage guidelines), Content (title guidelines), Platform considerations (platform-specific behaviors organized by OS), and Resources (related documentation and API links). Navigation aids include a left sidebar with the full HIG hierarchy, a right sidebar with on-page navigation, and a comprehensive footer with site-wide links.

keyTerms.definition: A UI component that creates a visually distinct group of logically related information and components using a visible border or background color.
The SwiftUI implementation of the Box component.
The AppKit (macOS) implementation of the Box component.
Apple's screen reader accessibility feature, mentioned in context of box titles helping users predict content.
A system color used by iOS/iPadOS for box backgrounds.
A system color used by iOS/iPadOS for box backgrounds.
A capitalization style where only the first letter of the first word is capitalized (like a sentence), recommended for box titles.

keyFindings: Boxes should be kept relatively small compared to their containing view to effectively communicate grouping
Nested boxes should be avoided - use padding and alignment for subgrouping instead
Box titles should use sentence-style capitalization without ending punctuation (except colons in settings panes)
Box titles improve accessibility by helping VoiceOver users predict content
iOS/iPadOS boxes use secondary and tertiary background colors by default
macOS displays box titles above the box by default
Boxes are not supported on tvOS or watchOS
visionOS supports boxes with no additional platform-specific considerations

defaultStyling.iOS_iPadOS: Uses secondary and tertiary background colors

designDecisions.decision: Use borders or background colors for visual separation
designDecisions.rationale: Clearly communicates that contents are grouped and related

designDecisions.decision: Keep boxes small relative to container
designDecisions.rationale: Large boxes lose effectiveness at communicating separation and can crowd other content
Nested boxes make the interface feel busy and constrained; use padding and alignment instead
While the visual appearance shows content is related, titles provide additional context and improve VoiceOver accessibility

mainContent.text: A box creates a visually distinct group of logically related information and components.
By default, a box uses a visible border or background color to separate its contents from the rest of the interface. A box can also include a title.

Prefer keeping a box relatively small in comparison with its containing view. As a box's size gets close to the size of the containing window or screen, it becomes less effective at communicating the separation of grouped content, and it can crowd other content.

Consider using padding and alignment to communicate additional grouping within a box. A box's border is a distinct visual element — adding nested boxes to define subgroups can make your interface feel busy and constrained.

Provide a succinct introductory title if it helps clarify the box's contents. The appearance of a box helps people understand that its contents are related, but it might make sense to provide more detail about the relationship. Also, a title can help VoiceOver users predict the content they encounter within the box.

If you need a title, write a brief phrase that describes the contents. Use sentence-style capitalization. Avoid ending punctuation unless you use a box in a settings pane, where you append a colon to the title.
No additional considerations for visionOS. Not supported in tvOS or watchOS.
By default, iOS and iPadOS use the secondary and tertiary background colors in boxes.
By default, macOS displays a box's title above it.
To submit feedback on documentation, visit Feedback Assistant.
